Answer: C F3

Based on the requirements provided, the most cost-effective subscription type would be the Microsoft 365 F3 plan.

The F3 plan provides access to Microsoft Teams, SharePoint Online, and Yammer, which are the required collaboration tools for the firstline employees. Additionally, it is a lower cost subscription compared to the E3 plan, which includes more advanced features such as Power BI and Office 365 ProPlus.

comments.content: Agree with you and really appreciate the time you took in order to give a complete explanation.

discussion.content:
This one looks incorrect. You can purchase software on either a monthly or yearly basis, (Nonperpetual) 

What is the Difference Between a Subscription Software (Nonperpetual) and a Perpetual Software License?

The core difference between the two is that a subscription (Nonperpetual) software is priced on a yearly or monthly basis and is an on-going subscription. 

A perpetual software license, on the other hand, is paid up-front in one, big lump sum.

https://www.sensrtrx.com/subscription-vs-perpetual-license-subscription-software-cheaper/#:~:text=The%20core%20difference%20between%20the,which%20covers%20upgrades%20and%20support.

Yes on all 3

So, the checkboxes should be filled as follows:

Statement 1: No
Statement 2: Yes
Statement 3: Yes
No Yes Yes

For the 3rd question the answer is Yes as the CSP is the owner of the support Level 1
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/learn/modules/identify-licensing-options-available-microsoft-365/4-cloud-solution-provider-model

For the 1st question the answer is now Yes :
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/partner-center/csp-on-premise-software

I suppose it depends on when the exam questions were last updated:

"Update January 19, 2021: We announced general availability of perpetual software licenses in the Cloud Solution Provider program."

"Targeting January 2021, partners enrolled in the Cloud Solution Provider program will be able to sell commercial perpetual software licenses for on-premises deployment through CSP."

https://blogs.partner.microsoft.com/mpn/expanding-opportunities-for-partners-in-the-cloud-solution-provider-program/

This is correct. 
1. You can buy software in CSP for on-prem use, but it will be PERPETUAL

choices.C: The company will be billed annually for a single Microsoft 365 license that can be shared among all employees.
choices.A: The company will be billed according to the amount of computing resources it uses each month across all users.
choices.B: The company will make a single payment for Microsoft 365, after which it owns the license for Microsoft 365 and can use it in an unlimited fashion.
choices.D: The company will be billed according to the number of user licenses acquired.

questions.question_text:
A company plans to purchase Microsoft 365.
You need to give management an overview of the Microsoft 365 pricing model.
Which of the following describes how the company will be billed for Microsoft 365?

You are the Microsoft 365 administrator for a company.
You need to track scheduled maintenance events in Microsoft 365 admin center.
Where can you track these events?

discussion.content:
This is correct.

Service Health vs. Message center

Service health:
Shows the current status of the service and details about service disruptions and outages. 

Planned maintenance:
Information is available on the Message Center. 

https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/office365/servicedescriptions/office-365-platform-service-description/service-health-and-continuity

D Message Center
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/office365/admin/manage/message-center?view=o365-worldwide

Selected Answer: D
Correct answer
I got this question in the exam on 2023-06-28.

Answer: D Message Center

The Web page has the Tip as follows:
https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoft-365/enterprise/view-service-health?view=o365-worldwide
 
Tip

Planned maintenance events aren't shown in service health. You can track planned maintenance events by staying up to date with the Message center. Filter to messages categorized as Plan for change to find out when the change is going to happen, its effect, and how to prepare for it. See Message center in Microsoft 365 for more details.

D is correct:

https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoft-365/admin/manage/message-center?view=o365-worldwide
"To keep track of upcoming changes, including new and changed features, planned maintenance, or other important announcements, go to Message center."

"You can track planned maintenance events by staying up to date with the Message center"

discussion.content:
Incorrect answer given in my opinion. Should be;

Add an Azure subscription to your MS365 tenant
Install the Azure Information Protection client

"To deploy Azure Information Protection, you must have the AIP client installed on any machines where you want to use AIP features."

https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/information-protection/requirements
According to this a client was required https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/information-protection/requirements - but I believe this is no longer relevant

Correct answer are:
1. Add an Azure subscription (https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/information-protection/deployment-roadmap-classify-label-protect)
2. Enable the default AIP policy (https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/purview/mip-easy-trials)

"Adicione uma assinatura do Azure ao seu locatário do Microsoft 365."
"Ativar a política padrão de proteção de informações do Azure."

I think it should be A,C,E
https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/information-protection/deployment-roadmap-classify-label-protect
Add an Azure Sub, Enable default (2nd option) and Enable the default (last option).

Correct answer is:
1. Add an Azure subscription
2. Enable the default AIP policy.

Given answer looks correct. (FYI: Azure Information Protection client was deprecated)
1. Add Subscription
2.Add Default azure information protection policy

Not your fundamental question but i think this is a clue: Your company has a 'Microsoft Office 365 ProPlus subscription'. so therefor only the apps so to say. If you do want more than you need an extra subscription. But an 'Azure' subscription? .. I would say an MS365 or so subscription. But you need an extra subscription I think.

These questions are probably out of date. The Azure Information Protection add-in for Office is in maintenance mode and MS recommend you use labels that are built into Office 365 apps and services. https://techcommunity.microsoft.com/t5/security-compliance-and-identity/azure-information-protection-and-the-information-protection/ba-p/3671070

Why not all 3 options, as both the client, and the policy are required, above the subscription?
https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/information-protection/requirements

Accourding to microsoft "To deploy Azure Information Protection, you must have the AIP client installed on any machines where you want to use AIP features. For more information"

In this case the right answer would be:
1. Add an Azure subscription to your MS365 tenant
2. Install the Azure Information Protection client

https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/information-protection/requirements

I think 
Add Azure subscription to 365 tenant
Install AIP client 
are correct.
https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/information-protection/deployment-roadmap-classify-label-protect#confirm-your-subscription-and-assign-user-licenses
The correct answer is Install client + create a custom policy. Azure sub is not required
I don't think "Add an Azure subscription" is correct. The licensing is covered by M365. A subscription is only needed if paying for other Azure services
